awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Rapid Point-of-Care Sterilization of Personal Protective Equipment for Frontline Healthcare Workers (COVID-19)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer, Phase I project is to improve public health.  During the COVID-19 pandemic, personal protective equipment (PPE), including filtering facepiece respirators (FFRs), have been critical to containing disease spread and protecting first responders and healthcare workers on the frontlines. Shortages of FFRs have led public health agencies to provide guidance in favor of FFR decontamination and re-use as a crisis capacity strategy. This project seeks to develop a cost-effective approach to support sterilization and re-use of personal protective equipment at the point-of-care. The technology seeks to develop and evaluate a simple, low-cost, sterilization receptacle for the effective, automated decontamination of FFRs. The aim is to enable first responders and healthcare workers to sterilize FFRs and prepare them at the point of care for re-use within minutes.  This capability can be useful both in the current and potential future pandemics.

This STTR Phase I project seeks to harness high voltage pulsed electric fields (PEFs) for decontamination and re-use of FFRs. In addition to killing bacteria and fungi, PEF has been observed to rapidly inactivate enteric viruses within seconds of exposure. PEF can also be used to electrically recharge FFR mask fibers prior to re-use.  The filtration efficiency of N-95 FFRs is improved by an intermediate layer of charged polypropylene electret fibers that trap small particles through electrostatic or electrophoretic effects.  A prototype will be constructed and evaluated on FFRs inoculated with respiratory viruses, including SARS-CoV2, in a clinical virology lab to directly demonstrate sterilization and recharge efficacy. The project will establish whether such a system will allow multiple sterilizations and fiber recharging cycles without affecting FFR function or efficacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In collaboration with The Mayo Clinic, Rush River Research has developed a portable device that uses high-voltage Pulsed Electric Field (PEF) technology to decontaminate and reuse Filtering Facepiece Respirators (FFRs) at the point-of-care. PEF is a non-thermal method that effectively eliminates pathogens on FFRs by creating pores in their lipid bilayer envelopes. This addresses the crucial need for FFR decontamination while maintaining mask integrity and performance. The research has resulted in an efficient, portable, and rapid sterilization system tailored for FFRs, which is essential for frontline healthcare workers. A prototype receptacle enclosure has been engineered for point-of-care sterilization, prioritizing portability, ease of use, and safety. 

The developed PEF system offers rapid, efficient, and effective FFR sterilization, meeting the need for timely decontamination in healthcare settings while remaining cost-effective and portable. This reduces the need for centralized sterilization facilities. Furthermore, the developed PEF generator has potential electroporation applications beyond mask sterilization, highlighting its versatility and value across various healthcare domains.

The completed Phase I program achieved four research aims:

1. Establishing the inactivation of a virus structurally similar to SARS-CoV-2 on fabric surfaces using a PEF to identify key parameters used for further investigation into the use of PEF for sterilization. 

2. Designing a novel PEF generator incorporating advanced electronic components to achieve precise control over pulse parameters. The developed PEF generator demonstrated improved performance compared to commercially available systems, particularly in terms of pulse rise/fall times, which are essential for effective viral inactivation. A specialized curved electrode structure and enclosure were developed to enhance the conformability of electrodes with mask geometries. The system's design prioritized user safety and ease of use, ensuring effective sterilization of masks while minimizing the risk of electrical hazards.

3. Evaluating the effectiveness of the prototype system. Initial effectiveness was established on a structurally similar virus, recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus (rVSV), which is harmless to humans. The results demonstrated significant viral load reduction, with PEF treatment achieving comparable efficacy to traditional sterilization methods in a fraction of the time.

4. Assessing the integrity and performance of face masks following multiple sterilization cycles using the developed PEF system. Standardized testing confirmed that the sterilization method did not compromise the protective capabilities of the masks, ensuring their continued effectiveness in filtering airborne particles.

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2024
Modified by: Julie Lundstrom
